Package dreisoft.tresos.datamodel2.api.model.path

Path conversion Thiis package contains Path Transfomer classes.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractPathTransformer
    Base Implementation to do path transformations.
    ASPathTransformer
    AUTOSAR path specific implementation to do path transformations.
    REPathTransformer
    This class represents a path transformer with the type 'REPath' that allows to substitute paths via regular expressions.
    XPathTransformer
    XPath specific implementation to do path transformations.

Package dreisoft.tresos.datamodel2.api.model.path Description

Path conversion

Thiis package contains Path Transfomer classes. Path transformers can be used to patch paths used (ASPath, XPath) in reference parameters and references to the parameter definition.

The classes in this package need not to be instantiated directly. Instead different methods of the DCtxt and subclasses use the Path Transformers.

Usage

The references of reference parameters can be changed by the convertRefs method: 

    ctxt.ref.convertRefs( new MXPath( "//*[@type = 'REFERENCE']" ), "ASPath", "/?/?/WrongNode", "/$0/$1/CorrectNode" );

The example above converts all references in the model that reference to a node named "WrongNode" via an "ASPath" inside any module configuration to point to a node named "CorrectNode" inside the same module configuration. The first argument to the call as an IMExpr that computes a list of nodes via XPath. The other arguments are handed to the Path Transformer:

  • type: The type of the tranformer (in this case "ASPath". Selects how the following arguments are interpreted and to which path the transformation applies.
  • match: An expression that the paths that should be transformed must match. In the case of the types "ASPath" and "XPath" this is a path in which '?' can be used as a wildcard
  • replacement: The path by which the input path is replaced. In the case of that the type is either "ASPath" or "XPath" this is a path in which variables ($<number>) are substituted by the strings that are matched by the wildcards of the match expression.

Transformer Types

The datamodel2 Public API provides three types of Path Transformers:

  • XPath: Allows to transform XPath paths
  • ASPath: Allows to transform ASPath paths
  • REPath: Allows to transform any path via an Perl regular expression

The "XPath" and the "ASPath" types use a path as match expression in which a '?' ('*' is already a reserved token in XPath paths) as a wilcard which matches an arbitrary length part of a path token name.

E.g.: 

    /Test_?/Test

matches "/Test_/Test" or "/Test_Something/Test" but not "/Test_Some/Thing/Test.

As wildcards are variable tokens that are determined by the actual path that is beeing transformed these tokens can be inserted into the replacement path via variables of the form '$' <variable-number> or '${' <variable-number> '}' where variable-number is the number of the n-th '?' in the match expression counting from 0: 

    /NoTest_$0/Test

as replacement transforms the matching paths described above into "/NoTest_/Test" and "/NoTest_Something/Test".

Both transformers also allow to match a prefix path when the match expressions ends with a '/': 

    /Test_?/Test/

Matches "/Test_Something/Test/Any/Data".

The variable with the variable-number n of the replacement expression where n matches the number of '?' in the match expression. The following replacement expression uses this feature to add the rest path to the substitute path: 

    /NoTest_$0/Test/NoTests/$1

This replacement expression would transform the path above into: "/NoTest_Something/Test/NoTest/Any/Data".

Besides the "XPath" and the "ASPath" transformers the "REPath" transformer is provided which uses perl regular expressions to transform paths (perl regular expressions are described in the JavaDoc of the class java.util.regex.Pattern. The following call transforms all reference that reference with an absolute XPath path: 

    ctxt.ref.convertRefs( new MXPath( "//*[@type = 'REFERENCE']" ),
    "REPath",
    "^(?:XPath:)?/(.*)$",
    "/NewPath/\1" );
